section.title: Linear functions and their graphs

introduction.p: Linear functions are the basis for most relationships that we can think about.

statement.p:
Linear function A relationship f(x) defined by either
y = f(x) = mx + b, with constants m and b, or
y=f(x)=y_0+m(x−x_0),with constant m and a point(x_0, y_0)
is called a linear function between the variables x and y. If the formula involves only adding and subtracting constants with variables multiplied by constants, the equation describes a linear function.
Slope The slope of a linear function passing through two points (x_0, y_0) and (x_1,y_1) is defined as the ratio of the change in output over the change in input ("rise over run”).

section.p: Notation In general, in biological applications we rarely have inputs/outputs called x and y – for example we have mass and volume. These labels, while different from what we are used to are meant to make problems more meaningful!

section.p: Interpolation Frequently we use linear functions to interpolate or predict values occurring between two known values. This technique is called linear interpolation, and is illustrated in the following example.
section.example:
HIV and AIDS Here we look at the onset of AIDS symptoms in the years after initial HIV infection. Four years after infection 17% had symptoms, and seven years after infection 33\% had symptoms.
Write the formula for a linear function that relates the percent of patients with AIDS symptoms to time (years measured since infection).
Define and interpret the slope and intercept (units included).
How many patients (what percent) have symptoms after five and a half years?
Using this model, at what time would you predict that half of all exposed patients have AIDS symptoms? What must you do to answer this question?
